They focus on latent variables that represent initial status (intercept) and rates of change (slope), capturing both the average growth trajectory of a population and individual deviations from that trajectory. By incorporating these latent factors, LGCMs provide a flexible framework for understanding individual differences in growth patterns and the underlying mechanisms driving change."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"LGCMs are particularly useful for investigating how specific factors influence developmental processes over time. They can include time-invariant covariates (variables that do not change over time) and time-varying covariates (variables that change over time) to examine their effects on growth trajectories. This allows researchers to assess complex relationships between variables across multiple time points, such as how an intervention might impact the rate of change in an outcome variable. By accounting for measurement error and capturing unobserved heterogeneity, LGCMs enhance the analysis of longitudinal data. They enable the identification of distinct growth patterns within subgroups of a population and facilitate testing theoretical models of development. Overall, latent growth curve models offer a comprehensive approach to modeling both individual and group-level changes over
